history.content:
Before you move to software, start with pen and paper or a whiteboard to just get your ideas out. After you've settled on the direction you want to go in, you can digitize your designs. Nowadays, the industry standard is Figma (https://www.figma.com/), which isn't difficult to start using. I think if you make your account with a Berkeley email, there's a free Education plan. For basic wireframing, the main tools you'll need are just drawing shapes and adding some text.

Honestly, you can use any software for wireframes as long as you communicate your ideas. You can draw stuff in Google Slides if you're more familiar with that. But in the long run, Figma is good to learn because it's built for product design, and is used by design teams in the industry.
I want to make an e2e design for an phone app. My understanding is that what I'm looking for to do that is some wireframing software, any recommendations?
history.subject: Wireframing software/websites/apps?
